item.title: Covid-variant vaccines fast-tracked with more investment
item.description: A new variant that can escape the current vaccines is the greatest risk of a third wave, experts say.

item.title: George Floyd killer Derek Chauvin asks for new trial
item.description: The white former police officer was found guilty of the murder and manslaughter of George Floyd.

item.title: How India descended into Covid-19 chaos
item.description: Experts tell the BBC that delays in decision-making worsened the crisis of India's second wave.

item.title: Covid-19: Extra cash pledge to fight variants and care home visiting rights
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Wednesday morning.

item.title: ‘Going out’ gear out and athleisure in for Boohoo
item.description: The online retailer said full-year sales jumped 41% as the pandemic boosted demand for loungewear.

item.title: Scottish election 2021: Sturgeon rules out 'wildcat' indyref2 vote
item.description: The SNP leader denies claims she could seek to hold an "illegal" referendum if her party wins a majority.

item.title: UK supermarkets warn Brazil over Amazon land bill
item.description: Almost 40 UK companies say proposed laws could accelerate deforestation in the Amazon region.

item.title: Trump launches new 'communications' platform
item.description: The former president releases a new website after his social media ban earlier this year.

item.title: Covid: Reused nose swab scam busted in Indonesia airport
item.description: Up to 9,000 passengers at an Indonesian airport may have been tested with washed and reused swabs.

item.title: Woman loses nearly £113k in dating site romance fraud
item.description: Rachel Elwell says she is facing bankruptcy after losing money to a scammer.

item.title: The Papers: 'Stop veterans witch hunt' and third jab for over-50s
item.description: Wednesday's papers react to the collapse of a trial of two ex-paratroopers who served in Northern Ireland.

item.title: The newborn calf that crashed our wedding
item.description: Wearing her wedding dress, dairy farmer Jessa Laws waded into knee-deep mud to aid a pregnant cow.

item.title: Stoke Mandeville: HS2 to move 3,000 bodies from medieval churchyard
item.description: A team of archaeologists is set to remove the old St Mary's Church and its burial grounds.

item.title: Elections 2021: 'Parents shouldn't have to fight for child's care'
item.description: A mum believes her disabled son is being failed by the social care system.

item.title: Indonesia coral reef partially restored in extensive project
item.description: Around 40,000 sq m of coral reef has been restored in Indonesia with plans to extend the scheme further.

item.title: Atlantic Ocean voyage ‘the hardest thing I’ve ever done’
item.description: Johnny Ward is part of a four-man rowing team that has crossed the Atlantic Ocean in a single boat.

item.title: Biden Carter: What’s going on in this picture?
item.description: How the apparent size difference between the Bidens and the Carters came about.

item.title: Covid and cancer: The young scientists working overtime to combat lockdown disruption
item.description: Lab staff are working long unpaid hours to reduce the impact Covid is having on cancer research.

item.title: Napoleon's incendiary legacy divides France 200 years on
item.description: Dictatorship and slavery taint the Napoleonic reforms that shaped modern France.

item.title: The company where your colleagues decide your salary
item.description: A software firm in Argentina is trying a radical experiment in employee transparency and democracy.

item.title: Covid cases at Everest base camp raise fears of serious outbreak
item.description: Climbers say a growing number of people have tested positive, despite government denials.

item.title: Wales election 2021: Who should I vote for? Compare party policies
item.description: Compare where the parties stand on key issues - from Covid-19 and the NHS to education and the environment.

item.title: 'I didn't know I wasn't a British citizen'
item.description: BBC Panorama speaks to young people who say their dreams have been crushed due to their immigration status.

item.title: Cardiff University team wants to change 'lad culture' perceptions
item.description: The students stepped forward to help chaperone women home after a hoax rape post on social media.

item.title: Covid-19: Care home residents can go on outdoor trips without isolating
item.description: People in residential care in England are now allowed low-risk trips outside without isolating afterwards.

item.title: Mahrez double sends Man City into first Champions League final
item.description: Riyad Mahrez scores twice as Manchester City seal an aggregate win over Paris St-Germain to reach their first European final in 51 years.

item.title: Real Madrid: Does Zinedine Zidane get the credit his Champions League wins deserve?
item.description: BBC Sport examines why a manager who has claimed almost every trophy available to him is yet to win universal respect.

item.title: Jose Mourinho: Why Roma job will be like no other for former Chelsea, Manchester United & Tottenham boss
item.description: For the first time in his career Jose Mourinho will not be expected to deliver trophies in the short term, so what can he expect at Roma?

item.title: My five years at Man City now make sense after reaching final - Guardiola
item.description: What Manchester City achieved in the last four or five seasons "now makes sense" says Pep Guardiola, after they make their first Champions League final.

item.title: 'Pole vaulting was killing me' - Olympic hopeful Bradshaw on the pressure to perform
item.description: How Holly Bradshaw escaped sponsor expectations, social media stats and her own pressure to love the pole vault again.

item.title: Scottish election 2021: Unusual - but extremely high stakes
item.description: The Covid pandemic has changed the character of this Holyrood election, but the constitution is still the main dividing line.

item.title: Election: Can Labour strike lucky twice in race for the Senedd?
item.description: Small numbers of votes could determine the outcome and the distribution of seats in the Senedd.

item.title: 2021 elections: What elections can I vote in this year?
item.description: National elections in Scotland and Wales and local elections in England are scheduled for 6 May 2021.

item.title: Are voters warming to the local elections?
item.description: Millions go to the polls on Thursday, leaving the big parties with much to think about.

item.title: 2021 elections: A simple guide to the Scottish, Welsh and local elections
item.description: A bumper crop of elections are being held on 6 May across England, Scotland and Wales.

item.title: Scottish election 2021: Does Scotland's future lie in or out of the Union?
item.description: BBC Scotland's James Cook hears from those both for and against another referendum on independence.

item.title: Election 2021: How do I vote and why could results take longer?
item.description: About 48 million people will be able to vote in a series of elections on Thursday 6 May.

item.title: Scottish election 2021: Has the campaign changed voters' minds?
item.description: Politicians have spent the last six weeks trying to persuade people to vote for them - but has it worked?

item.title: How many cases in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Northern Ireland is the latest part of the UK to lift some of the restrictions designed to stop the spread of Covid-19.

item.title: When can I holiday abroad, and which countries will be on the green list?
item.description: A new "traffic light" system for travel will classify countries as green, amber or red.

item.title: Covid: Restaurants and pubs are reopening, but what are the rules?
item.description: Northern Ireland follows England, Scotland and Wales in allowing venues to reopen outdoors.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People 40 or over in England are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the rollout continues.

item.title: Covid: When and how could social distancing stop?
item.description: Rules on hugging and social distancing in England are being reviewed.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk on transport?
item.description: As UK coronavirus restrictions continue to be relaxed, public transport could become much busier.

item.title: When does the stamp duty holiday in England and Northern Ireland end?
item.description: What is the stamp duty holiday and when will it finish?

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go.... and who with?
item.description: The rules on having a holiday in the UK have been relaxed - but restrictions remain.

item.title: Rare blood clots - what you need to know
item.description: We take a look at why these unusual clots happen and when they occur.

item.title: Covid: Is Europe lifting lockdown restrictions?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.
